page.title: 09WHALEY WATER WORKS.
page.content: Whaley Water Works was opened in 1938 to provide water for the Bolsover area. It was built by the Chesterfield and Bolsover Water Board. The water was obtained from two bore holes, Whaley Well and Gildwell. An average of 2273 cubic metres of water per day was drawn from Whaley with 545 cubic metres compensation water being returned to the stream. 1136 cubic metres of water was drawn from Gildwell where compensation water was not necessary. It was then purified by passing it through high pressure filters. Finally it was chlorinated to kill any germs. The water works was closed after it was discovered that the bore holes had become contaminated by the nitrates used as fertilisers by local farmers.
